Award.AwardTitle: Spatial-Temporal Modeling and Estimation of Epidemic Diseases and Invasive Plants Using Hawkes Point Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will provide new insights into the spread of epidemics and invasive species. In particular, this project will introduce new, more precise methods of estimating the spatial-temporal spread of epidemics. The results will also be more robust and less dependent on potentially faulty modeling assumptions compared with those based on currently used epidemiological methods. As a result, the project will lead to improved, more accurate estimations and forecasts, and a better understanding of the impact of policy decisions related to the spread of epidemics and invasive species. Such implications are important for preparedness as well as for urban planning, insurance, and public health policy. The results will be disseminated scientifically, rigorously, and responsibly, reflecting as accurately as possible the true threat presented by infectious or invasive species. This project is especially timely given the public health threat of recent disease epidemics such as Ebola.

This research project makes use of spatial-temporal Hawkes point process models to characterize the dynamics of both human disease epidemics and invasive species spread. Hawkes models are currently widely used in seismology to describe earthquake catalogs. Though these models have outperformed their competitors in earthquake forecasting experiments, and are often called Epidemic-Type Aftershock Sequence (ETAS) models based on the notion that earthquakes spread like epidemics, their use in application to the spread of diseases or invasive species has been sparse. Instead, epidemiologists have primarily used compartmental SIR models and their variants, which can have serious limitations when used to describe the detailed local behavior of an epidemic and can significantly overpredict counts of infections such as SARS. Indeed, existing estimates of epidemic spread rates are fundamentally model-dependent, and the addition of seemingly small changes to the models, or their parameters, can result in dramatic differences in local hazard estimates. This project will use and extend state of the art residual analysis techniques, such as deviance residuals, super-thinned residuals, and Voronoi residuals, in order to assess the goodness-of-fit of existing and proposed models and suggest ways to refine and improve them. Recently, a modified Hawkes model was fit to sightings of one invasive species of red banana trees spreading in a Costa Rican rainforest, and the results proved useful for estimating immigration and spatial-temporal spread rates, forecasting, and the detailed description of properties of the invasive species. This type of point process analysis will be extended to the study of human disease epidemics as well as other invasive species. This project will use recently developed statistical methods for estimating Hawkes point process models and their parameters, including non-parametric techniques for estimating the triggering function without relying on potentially flawed parametric models for the triggering rate, as well as modern integral approximation techniques that substantially add stability and computational efficiency to parameter estimates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research focused on using modern point process methods to more accurately describe and quantify the spread of infectious diseases and to aid in forecasting such events. Our investigations into the detailed nature of the spatial-temporal spread of infectious disease will help health care professionals and policy makers prepare for, predict, and mitigate the effects of future disease epidemics.

We discovered a new method for estimating this spread rate, and our method has slightly improved performance compared to previous methods, and has vastly improved computational efficiency. For instance, in one scenario with real data on 20th century human plague cases in the United States, whereas previous methods took about 7 hours to compute, the analytic method we proposed took only 1.3 minutes on the same machine. Such computational advantages enable further computations such as simulation based confidence intervals which we performed and which would otherwise be prohibitively computationally burdensome without our method.

We also proposed a new point process model for describing the transmission of infectious disease. We call the model a recursive model, since its key element is that the transmission rate of the disease depends on the prevalence of the disease, which in turn depends on the transmission rate, and so on. Compared to previously proposed models, the recursive model fits significantly better to data on diseases with variable transmission rates over time, such as the last 100 years of data on California Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever.

We accumulated and statistically analyzed a variety of important datasets on disease epidemic outbreaks, and obtained some important findings related to those diseases, especially the detailed characterization of their spatial-temporal spread rates. These included results on 382 records of ebola virus, including symptomatic cases and deaths, from the 2014 outbreak in West Africa. In addition to this recent ebola outbreak, we catalogued previous outbreak occurrences of ebola dating back to the first reported outbreak in 1976 in Zaire. A total of 25 outbreaks were logged from 1976-2014, and span a wide geographic range in Central and West Africa. We obtained historical data on U.S. plague over the past century, and on nearly half a century of measles data in Los Angeles, California, and have fit Hawkes models to these datasets. This research allowed us to quantify dynamic triggering, to compare the fit and predictive efficacy of Hawkes models to the SEIR models more conventionally used to such datasets, to explore efficient means of estimation for large point process datasets, and to investigate the effect of covariates such as Human Influence Index (HII) and population clustering effect disease transmission.

We have written fourteen journal publications already and are working on several more in preparation. We have mentored a Postdoctoral Scholar at UCLA, as well as three PhD students in statistics and two Masters students who were not funded by this project but worked on it with us anyway. We have presented our results internationally in the Keynote talk in the STAR Outreach Conference in Amsterdam in April 2016 and in the Institut Henri Poincare Seminaire Parisien de Statistique in Paris in June 2016, and the 2018 Joint Statistical Meetings (JSM) in Vancouver, Canada, as well as various other meetings and conferences. We are also working directly with researchers at the WHO, the California Department of Public Health, the Orange County Vector Control Division, and Departments of Public Health, Ecology, and Epidemiology at UCLA.
